awd_titl_txt: Eager: Inq-Blotter: Designing Supports for Teachers' Real Time Instruction
awd_abstract_narration:
Teachers are often frustrated because large-scale assessment data are neither timely nor adequate to understand students' needs so they can improve science instruction. What is missing are diagnostic, real-time tools to support teachers' practices and, in turn, students' learning. To address this challenge, the principal investigators will utilize Inq-Blotter, a dashboard, that lets teachers know who needs the most help and on which inquiry practices. Inq-Blotter will be integrated with Inq-ITS (Inquiry Intelligent Tutoring System) for middle school science, a learning environment in which students "show what they know" by conducting inquiry within virtual labs. Early data on dashboards for other domains (e.g. Mathematics) are promising, and pilot data collected with Inq-Blotter also shows promise in that it supports teachers' assessment practices. This project aims to develop Inq-ITS within virtual laboratories and to develop teacher professional development materials for supporting teachers content knowledge or inquiry practices.

Specifically, the principal investigators will develop instructional scripts, with which teachers can initiate class discussion or provide 1:1 support to students. They will conduct analyses to evaluate if the discourse afforded by the scripts helps to foster students' inquiry practices on their next inquiry activity (compared to control teachers who will not be provided instructional scripts). Important to the topic of classroom orchestration, the principal investigators will analyze teachers' discourse to study how alerting and scripts supports students' inquiry. The project combines techniques to measure students' inquiry practices at scale to study how teachers interact with their students when provided real-time alerts. In doing so, it can realize teachers' needs for formative assessments for science practices as well as students' needs' for learning inquiry. It will provide principles that can guide the design and development of alerting tools for teachers by advancing the stateof-the-art using a technologically-based approach to close the formative assessment loop for an ill-defined domain, namely, science inquiry. This work contributes to the well-acknowledged need to better support teachers' data use in classrooms, as well as support students in STEM learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Many students in the US underperform in science compared to students in other countries. In fact, American students currently rank 18th worldwide. This is problematic because of our country?s need for STEM workers, which are important to our economy and to maintaining our success in innovation. To ameliorate students? science knowledge, in 2013, the Next Generation Science Standards were released. These emphasize that students? develop authentic science competencies such as how to: generate testable questions, collect data to test these, interpret their data, warrant claims with data, and communicate findings in words. Forty-four states and D.C. have aligned their science standards to this policy document, which means that students must learn these competencies and teachers must be able to provide instruction on these competencies. However, typical multiple choice items are too coarse-grained to provide rich assessment data on students? competencies, and lab reports done in concert with hands on experiments are only valid for assessment purposes if students? writing skills are sufficient to explain what they know. Furthermore, neither of these provide real-time data to teachers, which is needed in for teachers? instruction of science to support students as they are learning, which is optimal for remediation.

 

In our EAGER project we sought to address teachers? need for a resource that would provide them with both real time data about their students? science competencies, identify which students were struggling and in what specific ways, and provide them instructional supports that could be used in real time as they monitored students (either remotely or in-person) while they did virtual science experiments in our science platform Inq-ITS (Inquiry Intelligent Tutoring System). As a result of this project, we were able to extend our teacher dashboard, Inq-Blotter, that works in concert with Inq-ITS, to include TIPS (Teacher Inquiry Practice Supports). These are 4 types of instructional support that teachers can use when helping individual students, small groups of students who are struggling on the same science competency, or the whole class (Inq-Blotter provides both whole-class alerts as well as alerts for individual students). We iteratively designed, piloted, refined our TIPS, and then implemented them into our teacher alerting platform. From August 2020 to November 2021, over 400 teachers and 36,000 students utilized Inq-Blotter. We collected data and conducted analyses from a subset of these in order to evaluate how teachers used the TIPS and how they impacted students' learning. In brief: 1) we identified five trends related to dashboard use in a remote setting, including three reflecting effective implementations of dashboard features and two reflecting the limitations of dashboard use, 2) we found that the use of TIPS improved students? learning, 3) we found that differences in how teachers used the TIPS yielded differences in students? learning, and 4) we found differences in the ways TIPS were used by teachers across different types of science competencies.

The project contributes to knowledge about science learning and teaching in a number of ways. The results provide critical data about how this technology can be leveraged in the classroom in real time to support both teachers? practices and students? learning and can also shed light on how students acquire science competencies. The classroom-based research addresses how an innovation like Inq-Blotter can be taken up by teachers and have sustained impact on education. Since the project uses new AI techniques, i.e., data mining, to achieve its goals, this project demonstrate the viability of AI for real time assessment and alerting for science. Lastly, since we conducted our research with diverse populations in science where many American students are falling behind, the benefits of this work have great potential for American students.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2021
Modified by: Janice D Gobert

Image
  • Alerting teachers when and how students struggle enables them to help more students. TIPS (Teacher Inquiry Practice Supports) provide actionable supports to help teachers help their students in real time while students conduct inquiry with Inq-ITS.
    Cameron Betts
    Copyrighted
    Janice D Gobert
    Inq-Blotter
